snippet: After a tumultuous first year in office, Mayor Bill de Blasio, a liberal who had staked his mayoralty on re-educating New York’s police force, is struggling to secure its basic trust.
abstract: Interviews reveal that deep rift between Mayor Bill de Blasio and New York Police Dept grew steadily for months before erupting into outright rebellion in wake of shooting deaths of two officers; de Blasio lost trust in series of political gaffes and miscalculations, including his close relationship with Rev Al Sharpton; mayoral aides contend police force is pushing back against reform-minded mayoral approach that dared to examine policing strategies in relation to race.

byline.original: By MICHAEL M. GRYNBAUM, J. DAVID GOODMAN and AL BAKER

lead_paragraph: After a tumultuous first year in office, Mayor Bill de Blasio, a liberal who had staked his mayoralty on re-educating New York’s police force, is struggling to secure its basic trust.

headline.main: In Police Rift, Mayor de Blasio’s Missteps Included Thinking It Would Pass
headline.print_headline: Mayor vs. Police: Many Missteps Behind the Rift
